p.s: In the following I will analyze the relationship between Macbeth and his wife and how she convinces him of murdering King Duncan by focussing on dialogue and language.
From the first line on Lady Macbeth makes clear that she is very invested into their plan by asking Macbeth questions and doubting his intentions (ll. 1-3).
Her wrong and uncommon sentence construction emphasize that (ll. 1-3).
When Macbeth confirms her worries by refusing to commit the murder through a metaphor for his good reputation (ll. 5ff), she starts to question his manhood.
With rhetorical devices and imagery about the courage he lost and his self-doubt (ll. 9-12) she puts pressure on him.
She compares their love to his cowardice and further degrades him by comparing him to a cat (l. 19).
Macbeth defends himself by saying that he does everything a man is obligated to do (l. 21).
Again Lady Macbeth questions his masculinity and even goes so far as to state that she is more of a man than he is.
She does that through the imagery of the breastfeeding baby she would be willing to kill (ll. 30-35).
This is also a reference to the scene where Lady Macbeth receives Macbeth's letter about the prophecies.
There she already doubts his ability to such acts of violence because he has too much of the milk of human kindness.
Macbeth's answer if we should fail (l. 36), a hesitant question, already shows that the lady's persistence was succesful.
When at first he rather confidently stated to not proceed further (l. 4) he now accepted her plan of the murder.
Similarly, Lady Macbeth now starts to include both of them in ther plans, since she is aware of his acceptance.
She uses pronouns like we (l. 39), our (l. 50) and you and I (l. 47) to underline that he is not doing it alone and she's there to help and support him.
Before she used lots of negative connotated words like coward (l. 18) beast (l. 23) to pressure Macbeth.
Now that she noticed he her manipulations are working she wants to motivate him further.
She describes her plan in great detail and uses more positive words like great (l. 50).
Her alliteration in line 42 wine and wassail also helps to convey her plans and underline her ambitions for carrying it out.
In the last part Macbeth relents and in a way compliments her by saying that she may only bring forth men children (l. 51).
So he indirectly says that she has the soul of a man and, referring to what she said before, is also more courageous, brave and coldblooded than he is.
By his choice of words terrible feat (l. 55) it is clear that he is not pleased or happy at killing the king, yet he still does it after his wife persuades him.
His metaphor to mock the time with fairest show (l. 56) show his willingness to deceive the world while also not quite believing in it.
It could also possibly be a reference to the play, because it is supposed to be shown on stage.

Furthermore this scene shows the dynamics between the two characters: Lady Macbeth dominates the dialogue with accusations and manipulations while Macbeth, troubled by his doubts, only defends himself.
While Macbeth is ambitious for power his self-doubts stop him and only through pressure from his wife he agrees to commit a crime.
All in all, Lady Macbeth persuades her husband in this scene by questioning his masculinity and uses imagery to help convey that mesasge.
She pressures him into accepting her plan, by otherwise declaring him not a man if he is not willing to do such acts of violence.
Macbeth, on the other hand, only defends himself after he is reprimanded.
In the end he wants to please her, so he agrees to her plan.
